docs.title: Welcome to BlobTrack
docs.text: BlobTrack is a computer vision tool designed to create generative visuals from video content. By leveraging the power of OpenCV, it extracts organic shapes and movements from source videos, allowing for real-time manipulation and high-quality export for VJ loops, motion graphics, and creative coding projects.

docs.title: 🚀 Key Features
docs.text:
• Advanced Detection: Isolate subjects using Edge Detection, Thresholding, or Color Ranges.
  • Dynamic Visuals: Apply real-time effects like rainbow cycling, breathing colors, and shape smoothing.
  • Real-Time Preview: What you see is what you get. Tweak parameters instantly.
  • High-Quality Export: Render your generative art to MP4 files.

docs.title: 🏁 Getting Started
docs.text:
If you are new to BlobTrack, we recommend starting with the Installation guide to get the software running on your machine.

Once installed, check out the User Guide to learn how to create your first visual.

docs.title: How It Works & The "Viral" Effect
docs.text: Targeting the intersection of technology and art, BlobTrack allows you to create visuals that feel "alive". But what is actually happening under the hood? And why does it look so cool?

docs.title: 🧠 The Tech: Computer Vision Explained
docs.text: At its core, BlobTrack uses OpenCV (Open Source Computer Vision Library), a powerful tool used in everything from self-driving cars to facial recognition.

docs.title: 1. Preprocessing: Cleaning the Image
docs.text: Before we can find "blobs", we need to simplify the video. - Grayscale: Color often distracts the computer. We convert the image to black and white intensities. - Blurring: Real-world video has "noise" (grain). We apply a Gaussian Blur to smooth out these imperfections, ensuring we detect large shapes rather than tiny specks of dust.

docs.title: 2. Detection: Finding the Signal
docs.text:
This is where the magic happens. We convert the image into a Binary Mask—an image made purely of black (background) and white (foreground) pixels.

  • Thresholding: A simple cutoff. "If a pixel is brighter than X, make it white. Otherwise, make it black." Great for silhouettes.
  • Canny Edge Detection: Calculates the gradient (rate of change) between pixels to find sharp edges. This creates those "wireframe" or "sketch" looks.
  • Color Segmentation: Converts the image to HSV (Hue, Saturation, Value) color space to isolate specific colors (e.g., "only show me the red parts").

docs.title: 3. Contour Finding
docs.text:
Once we have a binary mask, we use an algorithm (typically Suzuki85) to find the outlines of the white shapes.

"Contours can be explained simply as a curve joining all the continuous points along the boundary which have the same color or intensity." — OpenCV Documentation

docs.title: 4. Centroid Tracking
docs.text: We calculate the "center of mass" (centroid) for each shape. By comparing the distance of a centroid in Frame A to Frame B, we can tell if it's the "same" blob moving, allowing us to track it over time.

docs.title: 🌊 The Aesthetic: Why Go Viral?
docs.text: The visuals produced by tools like BlobTrack resonate deeply with current design trends.

docs.title: The "Liquid" & "Acid" Graphic Trend
docs.text: In recent years, design has moved away from the rigid, flat "Corporate Memphis" style towards something messier, organic, and chaotic. This is often called Acid Graphics or Y2K Futurism. - Fluidity: Blobs behave like liquid (mercury, water, lava). Humans are naturally attracted to fluid motion—it feels biological and alive. - Nostalgia: Reminiscent of early 2000s visuals (Winamp visualizers, iTunes visuals, Windows Media Player) but rendered with modern high-definition crispness.

docs.title: Generative Art
docs.text: Unlike a pre-animated video, generative art is unpredictable. It reacts to the input. This "controlled chaos" is fascinating to watch because it bridges the gap between the real world (the source video) and the digital world (the output code).

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: BlobTrack is built with Python 3.8+ and uses standard libraries like OpenCV and PyQt6. We provide an automated installer for convenience, but manual installation is also fully supported.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Before installing, ensure you have Python 3.8 or newer installed on your system. You can download it from python.org.

docs.title: Automatic Installation (Recommended)
docs.text:
We provide a shell script that automates the setup process, including creating a virtual environment and installing dependencies.

For Windows (Git Bash), macOS, and Linux:

  1. Open your terminal in the BlobTrackCv project directory.

  2. Run the install script:

    ./install.sh

  3. Once the script completes, you are ready to run the app!

docs.title: Manual Installation
docs.text: If you prefer to configure the environment yourself, follow these steps:

docs.title: 1. Create a Virtual Environment
docs.text:
It is good practice to run Python applications in isolation.

python -m venv venv

docs.title: 2. Activate the Environment
docs.text:
• Windows (Command Prompt / PowerShell): 

    .\venv\Scripts\activate

  • Windows (Git Bash): 

    source venv/Scripts/activate

  • macOS / Linux: 

    source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: 3. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Install the required packages from requirements.txt:

pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Running the Application
docs.text:
After installation, you can launch BlobTrack with:

python main.py

Tip

Make sure your virtual environment is activated before running the command! You should see (venv) in your terminal prompt.

docs.title: User Guide
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the entire workflow of creating visuals with BlobTrack.

docs.title: 1. The Interface
docs.text: The BlobTrack interface is divided into two main areas: the Preview Window on the left and the Control Panel on the right.

docs.title: 2. Loading a Video
docs.text:
To start, you need a source video file. Ideally, choose footage with good contrast between the subject and background for the best tracking results.

  1. Click the Select Video File button at the top of the Control Panel.
  2. Navigate to your video file (MP4, AVI, MOV, etc.) and open it.
  3. The video will begin playing in loop mode automatically.

docs.title: 3. Detection Settings
docs.text: The Detection tab controls what part of the video is turned into blobs.

docs.title: Detection Modes
docs.text:
Select one of the following modes from the dropdown:

  • Threshold: Uses brightness differences. Good for silhouettes.
  • Canny (Edges): Detects outlines and edges. Creates wireframe-like effects.
  • Color: Isolates a specific color range.

docs.title: Refining the Detection
docs.text:
• Blur: Smooths out video noise before detection. Increase this if your blobs are too jittery.
  • Min Area: Removes small specks or noise.
  • Max Area: Ignores blobs that are too large (e.g., the entire screen).
  • Threshold / Canny Controls: Adjust these sliders to fine-tune the sensitivity of the detection.

docs.title: 4. Visual Styles
docs.text: The Visuals tab controls how the detected blobs look.

docs.title: Shape & Outline
docs.text:
• Fill Shapes: Toggles whether blobs are solid or just outlines.
  • Smooth Mesh: Applies smoothing to the blob contours for a more organic look.
  • Outline Width: Controls the thickness of the blob borders.

docs.title: Color Effects
docs.text:
• Solid Color: Uses a single static color (pickable via the color wheel).
  • Rainbow Cycle: Automatically cycles through colors over time.
  • Breath: Pulse a single color's brightness up and down.
  • Speed: Controls how fast the Rainbow or Breath effects animate.

docs.title: 5. Exporting Your Work
docs.text:
Once you are happy with your visual:

  1. Click the Export Processed Video button.
  2. Choose a destination for your file.
  3. The app will process the video frame-by-frame.
    • Note: This might be slower than real-time playback depending on your settings.
  4. Once finished, you will have a high-quality video file of your creation!
